seqeas.subduction3d

Python-only module for the 3D ubduction zone simulations.

   1"""
   2Python-only module for the 3D ubduction zone simulations.
   3"""
   4
   5# general imports
   6import json
   7import configparser
   8import shapely
   9import meshcut
  10import numpy as np
  11import pandas as pd
  12import pickle
  13import cartopy.crs as ccrs
  14from abc import ABC
  15from cutde.geometry import compute_efcs_to_tdcs_rotations, strain_to_stress
  16from cutde.halfspace import strain_matrix, disp_matrix
  17from scipy.integrate import solve_ivp
  18from scipy.interpolate import interp1d, BSpline
  19from scipy.stats import circmean
  20from scipy.spatial.distance import cdist
  21from scipy.special import erf
  22from warnings import warn
  23from time import perf_counter
  24from dataclasses import dataclass, field
  25
  26# shorthand
  27SEC_PER_YEAR = 86400 * 365.25
  28""" Seconds per decimal year of 365.25 days """
  29
  30
  31def R_ecef2enu(lon, lat):
  32    """
  33    Generate the rotation matrix used to express a vector written in ECEF (XYZ)
  34    coordinates as a vector written in local east, north, up (ENU) coordinates
  35    at the position defined by geodetic latitude and longitude. See Chapter 4
  36    and Appendix 4.A in [misraenge2010]_ for details.
  37
  38    Parameters
  39    ----------
  40    lon : float
  41        Longitude [] of vector position.
  42    lat : float
  43        Latitude [] of vector position.
  44
  45    Returns
  46    -------
  47        The 3-by-3 rotation matrix.
  48
  49    References
  50    ----------
  51
  52    .. [misraenge2010] Misra, P., & Enge, P. (2010),
  53       *Global Positioning System: Signals, Measurements, and Performance*,
  54       Lincoln, Mass: Ganga-Jamuna Press.
  55
  56    """
  57    try:
  58        lon, lat = np.deg2rad(float(lon)), np.deg2rad(float(lat))
  59    except (TypeError, ValueError) as e:
  60        raise ValueError(
  61            "Input longitude & latitude are not convertible to scalars "
  62            f"(got {lon} and {lat})."
  63        ).with_traceback(e.__traceback__) from e
  64    return np.array(
  65        [
  66            [-np.sin(lon), np.cos(lon), 0],
  67            [-np.sin(lat) * np.cos(lon), -np.sin(lat) * np.sin(lon), np.cos(lat)],
  68            [np.cos(lat) * np.cos(lon), np.cos(lat) * np.sin(lon), np.sin(lat)],
  69        ]
  70    )
  71
  72
  73def crossmat(x1: float, x2: float, x3: float) -> np.ndarray:
  74    """
  75    Create the matrix for an input vector that if premultiplied with another
  76    vector will give the same results as cross-multiplying the other vector
  77    with the input vector.
  78
  79    Parameters
  80    ----------
  81    x1
  82        First element
  83    x2
  84        Second element
  85    x3
  86        Third element
  87
  88    Returns
  89    -------
  90        Cross-product matrix
  91    """
  92    return np.array([[0, x3, -x2], [-x3, 0, x1], [x2, -x1, 0]])
  93
  94
  95def correct_custom_utm(coordinates, utmzone, lon0, lat0):
  96    """
  97    Correct for a custom UTM Longitude/Latitude offsets by converting input coordinates
  98    back into Longitude/Latitude, re-adding the offsets, and then converting it back to UTM.
  99
 100    Parameters
 101    ----------
 102    coordinates : numpy.ndarray
 103        2D ECEF pseudo-UTM coordinates [m]
 104    utmzone : int
 105        UTM zone
 106    lon0 : float, optional
 107        Longitude offset []
 108    lat0 : float, optional
 109        Latitude offset []
 110
 111    Returns
 112    -------
 113    coordinates_utm : numpy.ndarray
 114        2D coordinates in standard UTM [m]
 115    """
 116    # define coordinate systems
 117    crs_lla = ccrs.Geodetic()
 118    crs_utm = ccrs.UTM(zone=utmzone)
 119    # get reference point in UTM
 120    coords_ref = np.array(crs_utm.transform_point(lon0, lat0, crs_lla))
 121    # add reference to current coordinates
 122    coordinates_utm = coordinates + coords_ref[None, :]
 123    # # convert to lon/lat
 124    # coordinates_lla = crs_lla.transform_points(
 125    #     crs_utm, coordinates[:, 0], coordinates[:, 1])
 126    # # add offsets
 127    # if lon0 is not None:
 128    #     coordinates_lla[:, 0] += lon0
 129    # if lat0 is not None:
 130    #     coordinates_lla[:, 1] += lat0
 131    # # convert back to UTM
 132    # coordinates_utm = crs_utm.transform_points(
 133    #     crs_lla, coordinates_lla[:, 0], coordinates_lla[:, 1])[:, :2]
 134    # done
 135    return coordinates_utm
 136
 137
 138def read_tet(filename, delete_invalid=True):
 139    r"""Read .tet files
 140
 141    Open a `.tet` file and read the :math:`m` vertices and :math:`n` triangles.
 142    It checks for duplicate vertices and eliminates them.
 143
 144    Parameters
 145    ----------
 146    filename : str
 147        Path to the .tet file
 148
 149    Returns
 150    -------
 151    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 152        :math:`(m, 3)` array of vertices locations
 153    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 154        :math:`(n, 3)` array of vertex indices forming a triangle
 155
 156    Raises
 157    ------
 158    RuntimeWarning
 159        If not all triangles are triangles or if they have extreme aspect ratios.
 160    """
 161    # get line number where it switches from vertices to triangles
 162    with open(filename, mode="rt") as f:
 163        for m, line in enumerate(f):
 164            if "TRGL" in line:
 165                break
 166    # load vertices
 167    vertices = np.loadtxt(filename, max_rows=m, usecols=(2, 3, 4), dtype=float)
 168    # load triangles
 169    triangles = np.loadtxt(filename, skiprows=m, usecols=(1, 2, 3), dtype=int) - 1
 170    # check for duplicate vertices
 171    vertices, triangles = remove_duplicate_vertices(vertices, triangles)
 172    # check triangles
 173    invalid_tris = np.flatnonzero([np.unique(tri).size != 3 for tri in triangles])
 174    if delete_invalid:
 175        del_ix = []
 176    if invalid_tris.size > 0:
 177        warn(
 178            f"Invalid triangle(s) in file '{filename}' found at line(s)"
 179            f" {invalid_tris + 1 + m}",
 180            RuntimeWarning,
 181        )
 182        if delete_invalid:
 183            del_ix.extend(invalid_tris.tolist())
 184    # check aspect ratios
 185    ratios = np.empty(triangles.shape[0])
 186    for i, subtri in enumerate(vertices[triangles]):
 187        elens = cdist(subtri, subtri).ravel()[[1, 2, 5]]
 188        ratios[i] = elens.max() / elens.min()
 189    if np.any(np.log10(ratios) > 1):
 190        liney_tris = np.flatnonzero(np.log10(ratios) > 1)
 191        ratioinfo = "\n".join(
 192            [f"line={i + 1 + m}, index={i}, ratio={ratios[i]}" for i in liney_tris]
 193        )
 194        warn(
 195            f"Found triangles with large aspect ratio in file '{filename}' "
 196            f"at:\n{ratioinfo}",
 197            RuntimeWarning,
 198        )
 199        if delete_invalid:
 200            del_ix.extend(liney_tris.tolist())
 201    # delete triangles if desired, keeping vertices without checking if needed
 202    if delete_invalid:
 203        del_ix = list(set(del_ix))
 204        keep = np.ones(triangles.shape[0], dtype=bool)
 205        keep[del_ix] = False
 206        triangles = triangles[keep, :]
 207    # done
 208    return vertices, triangles
 209
 210
 211def write_tet(filename, vertices, triangles):
 212    r"""Write .tet files
 213
 214    Write :math:`m` vertices and :math:`n` triangles to a `.tet` file.
 215
 216    Parameters
 217    ----------
 218    filename : str
 219        Path to the .tet file
 220    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 221        :math:`(m, 3)` array of vertices locations
 222    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 223        :math:`(n, 3)` array of vertex indices forming a triangle
 224    """
 225    # check
 226    assert triangles.ndim == vertices.ndim == 2
 227    assert np.max(triangles) == vertices.shape[0] - 1
 228    # get line number where it switches from vertices to triangles
 229    with open(filename, mode="wt") as f:
 230        for i, v in enumerate(vertices):
 231            f.write(f"VRTX {i + 1} {v[0]:f} {v[1]:f} {v[2]:f}\n")
 232        for i, t in enumerate(triangles + 1):
 233            f.write(f"TRGL {t[0]:d} {t[1]:d} {t[2]:d}\n")
 234    # done
 235    return
 236
 237
 238def force_normals(vertices, triangles, normals_up):
 239    """
 240    Enforce a direction for all the normals in the mesh.
 241
 242    Parameters
 243    ----------
 244    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 245        :math:`(m, 3)` array of vertices locations
 246    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 247        :math:`(n, 3)` array of vertex indices forming a triangle
 248    normals_up : bool
 249        If ``True``, force the normals to point upwards, if ``False``, downwards
 250
 251    Returns
 252    -------
 253    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 254        :math:`(m, 3)` array of vertices locations
 255    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 256        :math:`(n, 3)` array of vertex indices forming a triangle
 257    """
 258    # get current orientations
 259    signs = np.sign(
 260        [
 261            np.cross(
 262                vertices[triangles[i, 1]] - vertices[triangles[i, 0]],
 263                vertices[triangles[i, 2]] - vertices[triangles[i, 0]],
 264            )
 265            for i in range(triangles.shape[0])
 266        ]
 267    )
 268    # find the ones that need to be flipped
 269    if normals_up:
 270        change_dirs = signs[:, 2] < 0
 271    else:
 272        change_dirs = signs[:, 2] > 0
 273    # flip by changing the order of the second and third element
 274    if change_dirs.sum() > 0:
 275        triangles[np.ix_(change_dirs, [1, 2])] = triangles[np.ix_(change_dirs, [2, 1])]
 276    # done
 277    return vertices, triangles
 278
 279
 280def combine_tet(*args, return_sources=False):
 281    """
 282    Combine multiple .tet files into a single combination of :math:`m` vertices
 283    and :math:`n` triangles. It checks for duplicate vertices and eliminates them.
 284    Parameters
 285    ----------
 286    *args : tuple
 287        Paths to `.tet` mesh files.
 288    return_sources : bool, optional
 289        If ``True``, return a nested list matching each triangle index to a
 290        source file
 291
 292    Returns
 293    -------
 294    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 295        :math:`(m, 3)` array of vertices locations
 296    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 297        :math:`(n, 3)` array of vertex indices forming a triangle
 298    match_sources : list
 299        Nested list that contains the indices of the triangles belonging to
 300        each individual source mesh file (i.e., the ith list in `match_sources`
 301        contains all the indices for the ith file).
 302    """
 303
 304    # quick return if it's just a single mesh
 305    if len(args) == 1:
 306        vertices, triangles = read_tet(args[0])
 307        if return_sources:
 308            match_sources = [np.arange(triangles.shape[0])]
 309
 310    # full workflow
 311    else:
 312
 313        # load meshes
 314        list_verts_tris = [read_tet(mf) for mf in args]
 315        list_num_vertices = [vt[0].shape[0] for vt in list_verts_tris]
 316        list_num_patches = [vt[1].shape[0] for vt in list_verts_tris]
 317        num_vertices = sum(list_num_vertices)
 318        num_patches = sum(list_num_patches)
 319
 320        # create empty arrays
 321        vertices = np.empty((num_vertices, 3))
 322        triangles = np.empty((num_patches, 3), dtype=int)
 323
 324        # fill them sequentially
 325        # this also make the triangle indices continuous
 326        iv, it = 0, 0
 327        for vt, nv, nt in zip(list_verts_tris, list_num_vertices, list_num_patches):
 328            vertices[iv : iv + nv, :] = vt[0]
 329            triangles[it : it + nt, :] = vt[1] + iv
 330            iv += nv
 331            it += nt
 332        assert num_vertices == iv, f"{num_vertices} != {iv}"
 333        assert num_patches == it, f"{num_patches} != {it}"
 334        assert triangles.max() < num_vertices, f"{triangles.max()} >= {num_vertices}!"
 335
 336        # check for duplicate vertices
 337        vertices, triangles, old_indices = remove_duplicate_vertices(
 338            vertices, triangles, return_old_indices=True
 339        )
 340
 341        # if desired, create list of source indices
 342        if return_sources:
 343            # create raw list
 344            num_sources = len(list_verts_tris)
 345            match_sources = [
 346                np.arange(sum(list_num_patches[:i]), sum(list_num_patches[: i + 1]))
 347                for i in range(num_sources)
 348            ]
 349            # update it from the deduplicated set
 350            if old_indices is not None:
 351                for inew, iold in enumerate(old_indices):
 352                    for i in range(num_sources):
 353                        match_sources[i][match_sources[i] == iold] = inew
 354
 355    # done
 356    if return_sources:
 357        return vertices, triangles, match_sources
 358    else:
 359        return vertices, triangles
 360
 361
 362def remove_duplicate_vertices(vertices, triangles, return_old_indices=False):
 363    """
 364    Given a set of vertices and triangles, remove any potentially
 365    present duplicate vertices.
 366
 367    Parameters
 368    ----------
 369    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 370        :math:`(m, 3)` array of vertices locations
 371    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 372        :math:`(n, 3)` array of vertex indices forming a triangle
 373    return_old_indices : bool, optional
 374        If ``True``, return a list that matches old vertex indices to
 375        the new ones.
 376
 377    Returns
 378    -------
 379    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 380        :math:`(m, 3)` array of vertices locations without duplicates
 381    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 382        :math:`(n, 3)` array of vertex indices forming a triangle, reindexed
 383    old_indices : numpy.ndarray
 384        Array containing all the old indices, indexed to the new ones.
 385    """
 386
 387    # check if there are duplicates
 388    _, unique_indices, unique_counts = np.unique(
 389        vertices, return_index=True, return_counts=True, axis=0
 390    )
 391
 392    # there are duplicate values
 393    if np.any(unique_counts > 1):
 394        # sort the unique indices
 395        isort = np.argsort(unique_indices)
 396        unique_indices = unique_indices[isort]
 397        unique_counts = unique_counts[isort]
 398        # keep old state for testing
 399        old_patches = vertices[triangles]
 400        # release ties to previous variables
 401        vertices = vertices.copy()
 402        triangles = triangles.copy()
 403        # match unique to duplicate vertex indices
 404        match_indices = {
 405            i: [
 406                j
 407                for j in np.flatnonzero(np.all(vertices == vertices[i, :], axis=1))
 408                if j not in unique_indices
 409            ]
 410            for ii, i in enumerate(unique_indices)
 411            if unique_counts[ii] > 1
 412        }
 413        duplicate_indices = [
 414            i for i in range(vertices.shape[0]) if i not in unique_indices
 415        ]
 416        # double-check that every duplicate index is taken care of
 417        assert all(
 418            [
 419                di in [mi for sublist in match_indices.values() for mi in sublist]
 420                for di in duplicate_indices
 421            ]
 422        )
 423        # loop over every duplicate element
 424        for iuniq, idups in match_indices.items():
 425            # replace the duplicate index with the unique one
 426            triangles[np.isin(triangles, idups)] = iuniq
 427        # re-index all the vertices
 428        old_indices = np.arange(vertices.shape[0])[unique_indices]
 429        for inew, iold in enumerate(old_indices):
 430            triangles[triangles == iold] = inew
 431        # delete all duplicate rows
 432        vertices = vertices[unique_indices, :]
 433        # check that everything has worked
 434        new_patches = vertices[triangles]
 435        assert np.all(old_patches == new_patches)
 436        assert np.unique(vertices, axis=0).shape[0] == vertices.shape[0]
 437    elif return_old_indices:
 438        old_indices = None
 439
 440    # done
 441    if return_old_indices:
 442        return vertices, triangles, old_indices
 443    else:
 444        return vertices, triangles
 445
 446
 447def extend_mesh(
 448    vertices_in,
 449    triangles_in,
 450    dist_inf=1e7,
 451    directions=[True, True, True, True],
 452    use_normals=[False, False, False, False],
 453    normals_in=None,
 454):
 455    """
 456    Extend the mesh in the x and y directions along the respective other axis and
 457    constant z value. Includes corners.
 458
 459    Parameters
 460    ----------
 461    vertices_in : numpy.ndarray
 462        :math:`(m, 3)` array of input vertices locations
 463    triangles_in : numpy.ndarray
 464        :math:`(n, 3)` array of input vertex indices forming a triangle
 465    dist_inf : float, optional
 466        The distance to be considered infinite.
 467    directions : list, optional
 468        List of boolean flags indicating whether to extend a certain direction
 469        or not, ordered as [pos_x, pos_y, neg_x, neg_y].
 470        By default, all sides are extended. Set to ``False`` sides that should
 471        be excluded. Corners are only included if both directions are included.
 472    use_normals : list, optional
 473        List of boolean flags indicating whether to use the triangle's plane angle
 474        when extending or not, ordered the same as `directions`.
 475        By default, all sides are extended at constant :math:`z` value.
 476    normals_in : numpy.ndarray, optional
 477        :math:`(n, 3)` array of normal vectors of each triangle
 478
 479    Returns
 480    -------
 481    vertices_out : numpy.ndarray
 482        :math:`(p, 3)` array of output vertices locations
 483    triangles_out : dict
 484        :math:`(q, 3)` array of output vertex indices
 485    """
 486
 487    # input checks
 488    assert dist_inf > 0
 489    if any(use_normals):
 490        assert isinstance(normals_in, np.ndarray)
 491
 492    # build list of directions
 493    check_axes = [0, 1, 0, 1]
 494    check_dirs = [1, 1, -1, -1]
 495    off_axes = [(a + 1) % 2 for a in check_axes]
 496    off_dirs = [1, -1, -1, 1]
 497
 498    # initialize output
 499    n_off = vertices_in.shape[0]
 500    vertices_out = []
 501    triangles_out = []
 502    corner_help = []
 503    if any(use_normals):
 504        centroids = np.mean(vertices_in[triangles_in], axis=1)
 505
 506    # for each side and direction, create vertices and triangles
 507    for b, a, d, oa, od, n in zip(
 508        directions, check_axes, check_dirs, off_axes, off_dirs, use_normals
 509    ):
 510        if not b:
 511            corner_help.append([])
 512            continue
 513        # get all vertex indices at border
 514        i_max = np.argwhere(
 515            np.isclose(vertices_in[:, a], d * np.max(d * vertices_in[:, a]))
 516        ).ravel()
 517        n_max = i_max.size
 518        if n_max == 1:
 519            # the side is not a clear boundary, but is instead defined
 520            # by an intersection - let's hope they have the same depth
 521            i_max = np.argwhere(
 522                np.isclose(vertices_in[:, 2], vertices_in[i_max, 2])
 523            ).ravel()
 524            n_max = i_max.size
 525            # if it's still just a single value, we can't find the border,
 526            # and therefore can't extend it - let's hope it was the free surface
 527            if n_max == 1:
 528                warn(f"Can't extend axis {a} in the {d:+d} direction.")
 529                corner_help.append([])
 530                continue
 531        # sort both by increasing off-axes value
 532        sort_i = np.argsort(vertices_in[i_max, oa])[::od]
 533        i_max = i_max[sort_i]
 534        if n:
 535            # translate along plane angle
 536            # find the triangles with two vertices on the boundary
 537            tri_contains_border = np.isin(triangles_in, i_max)
 538            i_tri_at_border = tri_contains_border.sum(axis=1) == 2
 539            assert i_tri_at_border.sum() == n_max - 1
 540            # sort index by rising centroid off-axes
 541            sort_i_tri = np.argsort(centroids[i_tri_at_border, oa])[::od]
 542            i_tri_at_border = np.flatnonzero(i_tri_at_border)[sort_i_tri]
 543            # get the respective normal vectors
 544            normal_at_border = normals_in[i_tri_at_border, :].copy()
 545            # make sure the normal shows up
 546            i_normal_down = np.flatnonzero(normal_at_border[:, 2] < 0)
 547            normal_at_border[i_normal_down, :] *= -1
 548            # get the angles of the normals w.r.t. the vertical
 549            ang = np.arccos(
 550                normal_at_border[:, 2] / np.linalg.norm(normal_at_border, axis=1)
 551            )
 552            # take the average angle
 553            ang = circmean(ang)
 554            sign = np.sign(np.mean(normal_at_border[:, a]))
 555            # create final border points by translating the maximum border
 556            # vertex by the average angle
 557            new_vert = vertices_in[i_max, :].copy()
 558            i_border_max = np.argmax(d * new_vert[:, a])
 559            new_vert[:, [a, 0]] = new_vert[i_border_max, [a, 0]][None, :]
 560            tilted_dir = np.zeros((1, 3))
 561            tilted_dir[0, 2] = -np.sin(ang) * dist_inf * sign * d
 562            tilted_dir[0, a] = np.cos(ang) * dist_inf * d
 563            new_vert += tilted_dir
 564        else:
 565            # just translation along z
 566            new_vert = vertices_in[i_max, :].copy()
 567            new_vert[:, a] += d * dist_inf
 568        # create new triangles between (1, 2) original and (2, 1) new vertices
 569        i_new = np.arange(n_off, n_off + i_max.size)
 570        new_tri = np.concatenate(
 571            [
 572                [[i_max[i], i_max[i + 1], i_new[i]] for i in range(n_max - 1)],
 573                [[i_max[i + 1], i_new[i + 1], i_new[i]] for i in range(n_max - 1)],
 574            ]
 575        )
 576        # append
 577        vertices_out.append(new_vert)
 578        triangles_out.append(new_tri)
 579        # save indices of first and last old and new vertices for corner calculation
 580        corner_help.append([i_max[0], i_max[-1], i_new[0], i_new[-1]])
 581        # progress
 582        n_off += n_max
 583
 584    # concatenate new vertices and indices
 585    temp_vertices_out = np.concatenate(
 586        [vertices_in, np.concatenate(vertices_out, axis=0)], axis=0
 587    )
 588
 589    # check for corners to add
 590    for i1, b in enumerate(directions):
 591        i2 = (i1 + 1) % 4
 592        # we only have corners if both the current and next directions are extended
 593        if (not b) or not (directions[i2]):
 594            continue
 595        # get the axes and directions of both cornering sides
 596        a1, ch1 = check_axes[i1], corner_help[i1]
 597        a2, ch2 = check_axes[i2], corner_help[i2]
 598        if not (ch1 and ch2):
 599            continue
 600        # get the index of the corner vertex
 601        i_max1, i_new1 = ch1[1], ch1[3]
 602        i_max2, i_new2 = ch2[0], ch2[2]
 603        assert i_max1 == i_max2, f"{i1, b}: {i_max1} != {i_max2}"
 604        # translate to get the new almost-infinitely-far vertex
 605        new_vert = np.zeros((1, 3))
 606        new_vert[0, a1] = temp_vertices_out[i_new1, a1]
 607        new_vert[0, a2] = temp_vertices_out[i_new2, a2]
 608        if np.logical_xor(use_normals[i1], use_normals[i2]):
 609            # use the side that uses normals as the indicator for depth
 610            if use_normals[i1]:
 611                new_vert[0, 2] = temp_vertices_out[i_new1, 2]
 612            else:
 613                new_vert[0, 2] = temp_vertices_out[i_new2, 2]
 614        else:
 615            # average the two corner depths
 616            new_vert[0, 2] = (
 617                temp_vertices_out[i_new1, 2] + temp_vertices_out[i_new2, 2]
 618            ) / 2
 619        # create new triangles
 620        i_new = n_off
 621        new_tri = np.array([[i_max1, i_new1, i_new], [i_max1, i_new, i_new2]])
 622        # append
 623        vertices_out.append(new_vert)
 624        triangles_out.append(new_tri)
 625        # progress
 626        n_off += 1
 627
 628    # concatenate new vertices and indices
 629    vertices_out = np.concatenate([vertices_in, np.concatenate(vertices_out)], axis=0)
 630    triangles_out = np.concatenate(
 631        [triangles_in, np.concatenate(triangles_out)], axis=0
 632    )
 633
 634    # done
 635    return vertices_out, triangles_out
 636
 637
 638def split_mesh(vertices, triangles, patches=None, max_distance=None, max_depth=None):
 639    """
 640    Split the mesh into an inside and outside region based on distance to
 641    other patches and/or depth.
 642
 643    Resets the triangle indices for the two returned meshes.
 644    It also does not check whether the vertices and triangles are
 645    outside of the patches.
 646
 647    Parameters
 648    ----------
 649    vertices : numpy.ndarray
 650        :math:`(m, 3)` array of input vertices locations
 651    triangles : numpy.ndarray
 652        :math:`(n, 3)` array of input vertex indices forming a triangle
 653    patches : numpy.ndarray, optional
 654        :math:`(n, 3, 3)` array of patches to avoid
 655    max_distance : float, optional
 656        Maximum distance of the mash centroids away from the ``patches`` vertices
 657        to keep in the inside mesh.
 658    max_depth : float, optional
 659        Only keep mesh centroids in the inside mesh if they are above ``max_depth``.
 660
 661    Returns
 662    -------
 663    vertices_inside : numpy.ndarray
 664        Inside vertices
 665    vertices_outside : numpy.ndarray
 666        Outside vertices
 667    triangles_inside : numpy.ndarray
 668        Inside triangles
 669    triangles_outside : numpy.ndarray
 670        Outside triangles
 671    """
 672    # check if we're actually doing something
 673    assert (max_depth is not None) or (
 674        (max_distance is not None) and (patches is not None)
 675    )
 676    # initialize list of vertex indices to split off
 677    ix_v_split = []
 678    # find indices of vertices below below max_depth
 679    if max_depth is not None:
 680        ix_v_split.extend(np.flatnonzero(vertices[:, 2] < -max_depth).tolist())
 681    # find indices more than horizontal max_distance away from patches
 682    if max_distance is not None:
 683        # get unique vertex coordinates of asperities
 684        asp_vert_unique = np.unique(patches.reshape(-1, 3), axis=0)
 685        # get distance between all asperity vertices and all other vertices
 686        dists = cdist(vertices, asp_vert_unique)
 687        # get minimum distance to asperities
 688        min_dists = np.min(dists, axis=1)
 689        # get indices where that minimum is larger than max_distance
 690        ix_v_split.extend(np.flatnonzero(min_dists > max_distance).tolist())
 691    # get indices of triangles containing any of the split-off vertices
 692    ix_t_split = np.any(np.isin(triangles, np.unique(ix_v_split)), axis=1)
 693    ix_t_keep = ~ix_t_split
 694    # get unique vertex indices to split off or kept (there is overlap)
 695    ix_v_split = np.unique(triangles[ix_t_split, :].ravel())
 696    ix_v_keep = np.unique(triangles[ix_t_keep, :].ravel())
 697    # split vertices
 698    vertices_outside = vertices[ix_v_split, :].copy()
 699    vertices_inside = vertices[ix_v_keep, :].copy()
 700    # split triangles
 701    triangles_outside = triangles[ix_t_split, :].copy()
 702    triangles_inside = triangles[ix_t_keep, :].copy()
 703    # adjust vertex indices
 704    ix_old = np.arange(vertices.shape[0])
 705    ix_old_inside = ix_old[ix_v_keep]
 706    ix_old_outside = ix_old[ix_v_split]
 707    for inew, iold in enumerate(ix_old_inside):
 708        triangles_inside[triangles_inside == iold] = inew
 709    for inew, iold in enumerate(ix_old_outside):
 710        triangles_outside[triangles_outside == iold] = inew
 711    # done
 712    return vertices_inside, vertices_outside, triangles_inside, triangles_outside
 713
 714
 715def dzetadt_rdlog(dtaudt, alpha_h_vec):
 716    r"""
 717    Return the velocity derivative in logarithmic space given the current traction
 718    rate in linear space.
 719
 720    Taking the derivative of the steady-state friction gives an explicit
 721    formulation for the slip acceleration :math:`\frac{d \zeta}{dt}`:
 722
 723    :math:`\frac{df_{ss}}{dt} = (a-b) \frac{d \zeta}{dt}`
 724
 725    Recognizing that :math:`\tau = f_{ss} \sigma_E` and assuming
 726    constant effective normal stress leads to
 727    :math:`\frac{d \tau}{dt} = \sigma_E \frac{df_{ss}}{dt}`, which
 728    can be rearranged to give the final expression
 729
 730    :math:`\frac{d \zeta}{dt} = \frac{1}{(a-b) \sigma_E} \frac{d \tau}{dt}`
 731
 732    Parameters
 733    ----------
 734    dtaudt : numpy.ndarray
 735        Traction derivative :math:`\frac{d \tau}{dt}` [Pa/s] in linear space
 736    alpha_h_vec : numpy.ndarray
 737        Rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E`
 738
 739    Returns
 740    -------
 741    dzetadt : numpy.ndarray
 742        Velocity derivative :math:`\frac{d \zeta}{dt}` [1/s] in logarithmic space.
 743    """
 744    return dtaudt / alpha_h_vec
 745
 746
 747def get_new_vel_rdlog(zeta_minus, delta_tau, alpha_h_vec):
 748    r"""
 749    Calculate the instantaneous velocity change (in logarithmic space) due to an
 750    instantaneous stress change to the fault patches. We can kickstart the
 751    derivation from the expression in ``RateStateSteadyLinear.get_new_vel``:
 752
 753    :math:`\log (v_{+}/v_0) = \log (v_{-}/v_0) + \Delta\tau / \alpha_h`
 754
 755    and realize that we only have to plug in our definition for :math:`\zeta`
 756    to give us the final result
 757
 758    :math:`\zeta_{+} = \zeta_{-} + \Delta\tau / \alpha_h`
 759
 760    Parameters
 761    ----------
 762    zeta_minus : numpy.ndarray
 763        Initial velocity :math:`\zeta_{-}` [-] in logarithmic space
 764    delta_tau : numpy.ndarray, optional
 765        Traction stress change :math:`\Delta \tau` [Pa]
 766    alpha_h_vec : numpy.ndarray
 767        Rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E`
 768
 769    Returns
 770    -------
 771    zeta_plus : numpy.ndarray
 772        Velocity :math:`\zeta_{+}` [-] in logarithmic space after stress change
 773
 774    See Also
 775    --------
 776    alpha_h
 777    """
 778    return zeta_minus + delta_tau / alpha_h_vec
 779
 780
 781def flat_ode_rdlog(
 782    t,
 783    state,
 784    n_patches,
 785    v_plate_vec,
 786    K_int,
 787    K_ext_v_plate,
 788    v_0,
 789    alpha_h_vec,
 790    mu_over_2vs,
 791):
 792    r"""
 793    Flattened ODE derivative function for a subduction fault with
 794    rate-dependent rheology in the upper plate interface, and an imposed
 795    constant plate velocity at the lower interface (which can be ignored).
 796
 797    Parameters
 798    ----------
 799    t : float
 800        Current time (needs to be in function call for solve_ivp).
 801    state : numpy.ndarray
 802        1D array with the current state of the creeping fault patches,
 803        containing (in order) the cumulative slip and current velocity,
 804        and flattened so that its total length is `n_patches * 2 * 2`.
 805    n_patches : float
 806        Number of patches in the state array.
 807    v_plate_vec : numpy.ndarray
 808        2D plate velocities.
 809    K_int : numpy.ndarray
 810        4D tensor with the stress kernel mapping creeping patches to themselves.
 811    K_ext_v_plate : numpy.ndarray
 812        Stressing rate induced by the locked asperities.
 813    v_0 : float
 814        Reference velocity [m/s]
 815    alpha_h_vec : numpy.ndarray
 816        1D column rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E`
 817    mu_over_2vs : float
 818        Radiation damping factor
 819
 820    Returns
 821    -------
 822    dstatedt : numpy.ndarray
 823        1D array with the state derivative.
 824    """
 825    # reshape input state
 826    state2d = state.reshape(2 * n_patches, 2)
 827    # extract total velocities
 828    zeta = state2d[n_patches:, :]
 829    v = v_0 * np.exp(zeta)
 830    # get shear strain rate
 831    rad_damp_factor = mu_over_2vs * v / alpha_h_vec
 832    dtaudt = (
 833        np.tensordot(K_int, v - v_plate_vec, axes=[(3, 2), (1, 0)]) - K_ext_v_plate
 834    ) / (1 + rad_damp_factor)
 835    # get ODE
 836    dstatedt = np.concatenate((v, dzetadt_rdlog(dtaudt, alpha_h_vec)))
 837    # return
 838    return dstatedt.ravel()
 839
 840
 841def flat_ode_rdreg(
 842    t,
 843    state,
 844    n_patches,
 845    v_plate_vec,
 846    K_int,
 847    K_ext_v_plate,
 848    rho,
 849    alpha_h_vec,
 850    mu_over_2vs,
 851):
 852    r"""
 853    Flattened ODE derivative function for a subduction fault with
 854    regularized rate-dependent rheology in the upper plate interface, and an
 855    imposed constant plate velocity at the lower interface (which can be ignored).
 856
 857    Parameters
 858    ----------
 859    t : float
 860        Current time (needs to be in function call for solve_ivp).
 861    state : numpy.ndarray
 862        1D array with the current state of the creeping fault patches,
 863        containing (in order) the cumulative slip and current velocity,
 864        and flattened so that its total length is `n_patches * 2 * 2`.
 865    n_patches : float
 866        Number of patches in the state array.
 867    v_plate_vec : numpy.ndarray
 868        2D plate velocities.
 869    K_int : numpy.ndarray
 870        4D tensor with the stress kernel mapping creeping patches to themselves.
 871    K_ext_v_plate : numpy.ndarray
 872        Stressing rate induced by the locked asperities.
 873    rho : float
 874        :math:`f_0 / (a-b)` [-]
 875    alpha_h_vec : numpy.ndarray
 876        1D column rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E`
 877    mu_over_2vs : float
 878        Radiation damping factor
 879
 880    Returns
 881    -------
 882    dstatedt : numpy.ndarray
 883        1D array with the state derivative.
 884    """
 885    # reshape input state
 886    state2d = state.reshape(2 * n_patches, 2)
 887    # extract variables
 888    # slip = state2d[:n_patches, :]
 889    traction = state2d[n_patches:, :]
 890    # get current velocity
 891    vel = v_plate_vec * np.exp(-rho) * np.sinh(traction / alpha_h_vec)
 892    # get traction rate
 893    dtractiondt = (
 894        np.tensordot(K_int, vel - v_plate_vec, axes=[(3, 2), (1, 0)]) - K_ext_v_plate
 895    )
 896    # form state derivative
 897    dstatedt = np.concatenate((vel, dtractiondt))
 898    # return
 899    return dstatedt.ravel()
 900
 901
 902def flat_run_rdlog(
 903    t_eval,
 904    i_break,
 905    i_eq,
 906    K_int,
 907    K_ext_v_plate,
 908    v_plate_vec,
 909    v_init,
 910    delta_tau_bounded,
 911    delta_tau_bounded_nonuni,
 912    v_0,
 913    alpha_h_vec,
 914    mu_over_2vs,
 915    v_max,
 916    atol,
 917    rtol,
 918    spinup_atol,
 919    spinup_rtol,
 920    verbose,
 921):
 922    r"""
 923    Run the rate-dependent simulation.
 924
 925    Parameters
 926    ----------
 927    t_eval : numpy.ndarray
 928        Evaluation times [s]
 929    i_break : numpy.ndarray
 930        Integer indices of cycle breaks [-]
 931    i_eq : numpy.ndarray
 932        Integer indices of earthquakes within sequence [-]
 933    K_int : numpy.ndarray
 934        Internal stress kernel [Pa/m]
 935    K_ext_v_plate : numpy.ndarray
 936        Stressing rate induced by the locked asperities.
 937    v_plate_vec : numpy.ndarray
 938        Plate velocity for all creeping patches [m/s]
 939    v_init : numpy.ndarray
 940        Initial velocity of the fault patches, in the dimensions of the rheology
 941    delta_tau_bounded : numpy.ndarray
 942        Bounded coseismic stress change [Pa]
 943    v_0 : float
 944        Reference velocity [m/s]
 945    alpha_h_vec : numpy.ndarray
 946        Upper interface rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa]
 947    mu_over_2vs : float
 948        Radiation damping factor :math:`\mu / 2 v_s`, where :math:`\mu` is the shear
 949        modulus [Pa] and :math:`v_s` is the shear wave velocity [m/s]
 950    v_max : float
 951        Maximum velocity that a patch can have during the integration [m/s], or None
 952        if not limit.
 953    atol : float
 954        Absolute tolerance of ODE integrator
 955    rtol : float
 956        Relative tolerance of ODE integrator
 957    spinup_atol : float
 958        Absolute tolerance of spinup controller
 959    spinup_rtol : float
 960        Relative tolerance of spinup controller
 961    verbose : bool
 962        Print integration progress.
 963
 964    Returns
 965    -------
 966    sim_state : numpy.ndarray
 967        Full state variable at the end of the integration.
 968    """
 969
 970    # initialize parameters
 971    n_eval = t_eval.size
 972    n_slips = delta_tau_bounded.shape[0]
 973    n_patches = K_int.shape[0]
 974    assert np.all(np.diff(t_eval) > 0)
 975    assert (
 976        n_patches
 977        == K_ext_v_plate.shape[0]
 978        == v_plate_vec.shape[0]
 979        == v_init.shape[0]
 980        == alpha_h_vec.shape[0]
 981    )
 982
 983    # initialize arrays
 984    signs = np.sign(v_plate_vec)
 985    assert np.all(signs == np.sign(v_init)) and np.all(signs > 0)
 986    v_init = np.abs(v_init)
 987    s_minus_upper = np.zeros((n_patches, 2))
 988    zeta_minus_upper = np.log(v_init / v_0)
 989    sim_state = np.full((2 * n_patches, 2, n_eval), np.nan)
 990    state_plus = np.concatenate((s_minus_upper, zeta_minus_upper))
 991
 992    # make flat ODE function arguments
 993    args = (n_patches, v_plate_vec, K_int, K_ext_v_plate, v_0, alpha_h_vec, mu_over_2vs)
 994
 995    # integrate
 996    spun_up = 0
 997    i_slip = 0
 998    steps = np.sort(np.concatenate((i_eq, i_break)))
 999    i = 0
1000    if delta_tau_bounded_nonuni is not None:
1001        # need to get the indices of the last n_slips_obs events
1002        n_slips_obs = delta_tau_bounded_nonuni.shape[0]
1003        i_eq_nonuni = i_eq[-n_slips_obs:].tolist()
1004    else:
1005        i_eq_nonuni = []
1006    if verbose:
1007        print("0", end="", flush=True)
1008        ii = 1
1009    while i < steps.size - 1:
1010        # get indices
1011        ji, jf = steps[i], steps[i + 1]
1012        ti, tf = t_eval[ji], t_eval[jf]
1013        # call integrator
1014        sol = solve_ivp(
1015            flat_ode_rdlog,
1016            t_span=[ti, tf],
1017            y0=state_plus.ravel(),
1018            t_eval=t_eval[ji : jf + 1],
1019            method="RK45",
1020            args=args,
1021            atol=atol,
1022            rtol=rtol,
1023        )
1024        success = sol.success
1025        if success:
1026            sol = sol.y.reshape(2 * n_patches, 2, -1)
1027        else:
1028            raise RuntimeError("Integrator failed.")
1029        # save state to output array
1030        sim_state[:, :, ji : jf + 1] = sol
1031        # can already stop here if this is the last interval
1032        if i == steps.size - 2:
1033            break
1034        # at the end of a full cycle, check the early stopping criteria
1035        if (not spun_up) and (i > n_slips) and (jf in i_break):
1036            if verbose:
1037                print(f"{ii}", end="", flush=True)
1038                ii += 1
1039            old_full_state = sim_state[
1040                :, :, steps[i - 2 * n_slips - 1] : steps[i - n_slips]
1041            ]
1042            new_full_state = sim_state[:, :, steps[i - n_slips] : steps[i + 1]]
1043            old_zeta_upper = old_full_state[n_patches:, :, -1]
1044            new_zeta_upper = new_full_state[n_patches:, :, -1]
1045            lhs_upper = np.abs(new_zeta_upper - old_zeta_upper)
1046            rhs_upper = spinup_atol + spinup_rtol * np.fmax(
1047                np.abs(new_zeta_upper), np.abs(old_zeta_upper)
1048            )
1049            stop_now = np.all(lhs_upper <= rhs_upper)
1050            if stop_now:
1051                spun_up = jf
1052                # advance i to the last cycle (don't forget the general advance later)
1053                if verbose:
1054                    print(">", end="", flush=True)
1055                i = steps.size - n_slips - 3
1056        elif (not spun_up) and (jf in i_break) and verbose:
1057            print(f"{ii}", end="", flush=True)
1058            ii += 1
1059        elif spun_up and (jf in i_break):
1060            break
1061        # apply step change only if there is one
1062        if jf in i_eq:
1063            if verbose:
1064                print(".", end="", flush=True)
1065            state_upper = sol[:, :, -1]
1066            s_minus_upper = state_upper[:n_patches, :]
1067            zeta_minus_upper = state_upper[n_patches:, :]
1068            s_plus_upper = s_minus_upper.copy()
1069            if spun_up and (jf in i_eq_nonuni):
1070                i_slip_nonuni = i_eq_nonuni.index(jf)
1071                zeta_plus_upper = get_new_vel_rdlog(
1072                    zeta_minus_upper,
1073                    delta_tau_bounded_nonuni[i_slip_nonuni, :, :],
1074                    alpha_h_vec,
1075                )
1076            else:
1077                zeta_plus_upper = get_new_vel_rdlog(
1078                    zeta_minus_upper, delta_tau_bounded[i_slip, :, :], alpha_h_vec
1079                )
1080            if v_max is not None:
1081                v_plus_upper = v_0 * np.exp(zeta_plus_upper)
1082                v_plus_upper_norm = np.linalg.norm(v_plus_upper, axis=1)
1083                if np.any(v_plus_upper_norm > v_max):
1084                    v_plus_upper *= (
1085                        np.clip(v_plus_upper_norm, a_min=None, a_max=v_max)
1086                        / v_plus_upper_norm
1087                    )[:, None]
1088                    zeta_plus_upper = np.log(v_plus_upper / v_0)
1089            state_plus = np.concatenate((s_plus_upper, zeta_plus_upper))
1090            i_slip = (i_slip + 1) % n_slips
1091        else:
1092            state_plus = sol[:, :, -1]
1093        # advance
1094        i += 1
1095
1096    # warn if we never spun up
1097    if not spun_up:
1098        print(f"Simulation did not spin up after {len(i_break) - 1} cycles!")
1099
1100    # convert from log to linear velocity
1101    sim_state[n_patches:, :, :] = v_0 * np.exp(sim_state[n_patches:, :, :])
1102
1103    # done
1104    return sim_state
1105
1106
1107def flat_run_rdreg(
1108    t_eval,
1109    i_break,
1110    i_eq,
1111    K_int,
1112    K_ext_v_plate,
1113    v_plate_vec,
1114    v_init,
1115    delta_tau_bounded,
1116    delta_tau_bounded_nonuni,
1117    slip_taper_vec,
1118    slip_taper_vec_nonuni,
1119    rho,
1120    alpha_h_vec,
1121    mu_over_2vs,
1122    v_max,
1123    atol,
1124    rtol,
1125    spinup_atol,
1126    spinup_rtol,
1127    verbose,
1128):
1129    r"""
1130    Run the regularized rate-dependent simulation.
1131
1132    Parameters
1133    ----------
1134    t_eval : numpy.ndarray
1135        Evaluation times [s]
1136    i_break : numpy.ndarray
1137        Integer indices of cycle breaks [-]
1138    i_eq : numpy.ndarray
1139        Integer indices of earthquakes within sequence [-]
1140    K_int : numpy.ndarray
1141        Internal stress kernel [Pa/m]
1142    K_ext_v_plate : numpy.ndarray
1143        Stressing rate induced by the locked asperities.
1144    v_plate_vec : numpy.ndarray
1145        Plate velocity for all creeping patches [m/s]
1146    v_init : numpy.ndarray
1147        Initial velocity of the fault patches, in the dimensions of the rheology
1148    delta_tau_bounded : numpy.ndarray
1149        Bounded coseismic stress change [Pa]
1150    delta_tau_bounded_nonuni : numpy.ndarray
1151        Bounded coseismic stress change for nonuniform earthquakes [Pa]
1152    slip_taper_vec : numpy.ndarray
1153        Tapered slip [m]
1154    slip_taper_vec_nonuni : numpy.ndarray
1155        Tapered slip for nonuniform earthquakes [m]
1156    rho : float
1157        :math:`f_0 / (a-b)` [-]
1158    alpha_h_vec : numpy.ndarray
1159        Upper interface rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa]
1160    mu_over_2vs : float
1161        Radiation damping factor :math:`\mu / 2 v_s`, where :math:`\mu` is the shear
1162        modulus [Pa] and :math:`v_s` is the shear wave velocity [m/s]
1163    v_max : float
1164        Maximum velocity that a patch can have during the integration [m/s], or None
1165        if not limit.
1166    atol : float
1167        Absolute tolerance of ODE integrator
1168    rtol : float
1169        Relative tolerance of ODE integrator
1170    spinup_atol : float
1171        Absolute tolerance of spinup controller
1172    spinup_rtol : float
1173        Relative tolerance of spinup controller
1174    verbose : bool
1175        Print integration progress.
1176
1177    Returns
1178    -------
1179    sim_state : numpy.ndarray
1180        Full state variable at the end of the integration.
1181    """
1182
1183    # initialize parameters
1184    n_eval = t_eval.size
1185    n_slips = delta_tau_bounded.shape[0]
1186    n_patches = K_int.shape[0]
1187    assert np.all(np.diff(t_eval) > 0)
1188    assert (
1189        n_patches
1190        == K_ext_v_plate.shape[0]
1191        == v_plate_vec.shape[0]
1192        == v_init.shape[0]
1193        == alpha_h_vec.shape[0]
1194    )
1195    assert not np.logical_xor(delta_tau_bounded_nonuni is None, slip_taper_vec is None)
1196
1197    # initialize arrays
1198    s_minus_upper = np.zeros((n_patches, 2))
1199    # tau_minus_upper = rho * np.broadcast_to(alpha_h_vec, (n_patches, 2))
1200    tau_minus_upper = np.arcsinh(v_init / v_plate_vec * np.exp(rho)) * alpha_h_vec
1201    sim_state = np.full((2 * n_patches, 2, n_eval), np.nan)
1202    state_plus = np.concatenate((s_minus_upper, tau_minus_upper))
1203
1204    # make flat ODE function arguments
1205    args = (n_patches, v_plate_vec, K_int, K_ext_v_plate, rho, alpha_h_vec, mu_over_2vs)
1206
1207    # integrate
1208    spun_up = 0
1209    i_slip = 0
1210    steps = np.sort(np.concatenate((i_eq, i_break)))
1211    i = 0
1212    if delta_tau_bounded_nonuni is not None:
1213        # need to get the indices of the last n_slips_obs events
1214        n_slips_obs = delta_tau_bounded_nonuni.shape[0]
1215        i_eq_nonuni = i_eq[-n_slips_obs:].tolist()
1216    else:
1217        i_eq_nonuni = []
1218    if verbose:
1219        print("0", end="", flush=True)
1220        ii = 1
1221    while i < steps.size - 1:
1222        # get indices
1223        ji, jf = steps[i], steps[i + 1]
1224        ti, tf = t_eval[ji], t_eval[jf]
1225        # call integrator
1226        sol = solve_ivp(
1227            flat_ode_rdreg,
1228            t_span=[ti, tf],
1229            y0=state_plus.ravel(),
1230            t_eval=t_eval[ji : jf + 1],
1231            method="RK45",
1232            args=args,
1233            atol=atol,
1234            rtol=rtol,
1235        )
1236        success = sol.success
1237        if success:
1238            sol = sol.y.reshape(2 * n_patches, 2, -1)
1239        else:
1240            raise RuntimeError("Integrator failed.")
1241        # save state to output array
1242        sim_state[:, :, ji : jf + 1] = sol
1243        # can already stop here if this is the last interval
1244        if i == steps.size - 2:
1245            break
1246        # at the end of a full cycle, check the early stopping criteria
1247        if (not spun_up) and (i > n_slips) and (jf in i_break):
1248            if verbose:
1249                print(f"{ii}", end="", flush=True)
1250                ii += 1
1251            old_full_state = sim_state[
1252                :, :, steps[i - 2 * n_slips - 1] : steps[i - n_slips]
1253            ]
1254            new_full_state = sim_state[:, :, steps[i - n_slips] : steps[i + 1]]
1255            old_tau_upper = old_full_state[n_patches:, :, -1]
1256            new_tau_upper = new_full_state[n_patches:, :, -1]
1257            lhs_upper = np.abs(new_tau_upper - old_tau_upper)
1258            rhs_upper = spinup_atol + spinup_rtol * np.fmax(
1259                np.abs(new_tau_upper), np.abs(old_tau_upper)
1260            )
1261            stop_now = np.all(lhs_upper <= rhs_upper)
1262            if stop_now:
1263                spun_up = jf
1264                # advance i to the last cycle (don't forget the general advance later)
1265                if verbose:
1266                    print(">", end="", flush=True)
1267                i = steps.size - n_slips - 3
1268        elif (not spun_up) and (jf in i_break) and verbose:
1269            print(f"{ii}", end="", flush=True)
1270            ii += 1
1271        elif spun_up and (jf in i_break):
1272            break
1273        # apply step change only if there is one
1274        if jf in i_eq:
1275            if verbose:
1276                print(".", end="", flush=True)
1277            state_upper = sol[:, :, -1]
1278            s_minus_upper = state_upper[:n_patches, :]
1279            tau_minus_upper = state_upper[n_patches:, :]
1280            s_plus_upper = s_minus_upper.copy()
1281            if spun_up and (jf in i_eq_nonuni):
1282                i_slip_nonuni = i_eq_nonuni.index(jf)
1283                s_plus_upper = (
1284                    s_minus_upper + slip_taper_vec_nonuni[i_slip_nonuni, :, :]
1285                )
1286                tau_plus_upper = (
1287                    tau_minus_upper + delta_tau_bounded_nonuni[i_slip_nonuni, :, :]
1288                )
1289            else:
1290                s_plus_upper = s_minus_upper + slip_taper_vec[i_slip, :, :]
1291                tau_plus_upper = tau_minus_upper + delta_tau_bounded[i_slip, :, :]
1292            if v_max is not None:
1293                v_plus_upper = (
1294                    v_plate_vec * np.exp(-rho) * np.sinh(tau_plus_upper / alpha_h_vec)
1295                )
1296                v_plus_upper_norm = np.linalg.norm(v_plus_upper, axis=1)
1297                if np.any(v_plus_upper_norm > v_max):
1298                    v_plus_upper *= (
1299                        np.clip(v_plus_upper_norm, a_min=None, a_max=v_max)
1300                        / v_plus_upper_norm
1301                    )[:, None]
1302                    tau_plus_upper = (
1303                        np.arcsinh((v_plus_upper / v_plate_vec) * np.exp(rho))
1304                        * alpha_h_vec
1305                    )
1306            state_plus = np.concatenate((s_plus_upper, tau_plus_upper))
1307            i_slip = (i_slip + 1) % n_slips
1308        else:
1309            state_plus = sol[:, :, -1]
1310        # advance
1311        i += 1
1312
1313    # warn if we never spun up
1314    if not spun_up:
1315        print(f"Simulation did not spin up after {len(i_break) - 1} cycles!")
1316
1317    # convert from traction to linear velocity
1318    sim_state[n_patches:, :, :] = (
1319        v_plate_vec[:, :, None]
1320        * np.exp(-rho)
1321        * np.sinh(sim_state[n_patches:, :, :] / alpha_h_vec[:, :, None])
1322    )
1323
1324    # done
1325    return sim_state
1326
1327
1328def get_surface_displacements(obs_slip_ts, G):
1329    """
1330    Calculate the surface displacements given a slip timeseries and the Green's functions.
1331
1332    Parameters
1333    ----------
1334    slip_ts : numpy.ndarray
1335        Array of shape `(n_patches, 2, n_eval)` where `n_patches` is the number
1336        of patches and `n_eval` is the number of timesteps.
1337    G : numpy.ndarray
1338        4D tensor of Green's functions of shape :math:`(m, 3, n, 3)`.
1339
1340    Returns
1341    -------
1342    surf_disp : numpy.ndarray
1343        Surface displacement timeseries.
1344    """
1345    # this is equivalent to calling the single-timestep tensor product in a loop
1346    # over the n_eval time steps
1347    return np.tensordot(G[:, :, :, :2], obs_slip_ts, axes=[(3, 2), (1, 0)])
1348
1349
1350def rotation_matrix_around_vector(theta, vector):
1351    """
1352    Calculates the rotation matrix used to rotate a right-handed coordinate system
1353    counterclockwise around a vector when multiplied from the right.
1354
1355    Parameters
1356    ----------
1357    theta : float
1358        Rotation angle [rad]
1359    vector : numpy.ndarray
1360        Unit rotation vector
1361
1362    Returns
1363    -------
1364    R : numpy.ndarray
1365        Rotation matrix
1366    """
1367    assert vector.size == 3
1368    return (
1369        np.cos(theta) * np.eye(3)
1370        + np.sin(-theta) * np.cross(vector, -np.eye(3))
1371        + (1 - np.cos(theta)) * np.outer(vector, vector)
1372    )
1373
1374
1375def eulerpole2rotvec(euler_pole, euler_pole_covariance=None):
1376    r"""
1377    Convert an Euler pole (and optionally, its formal covariance) into a rotation
1378    vector and associated covariance matrix. Based on [goudarzi14]_.
1379
1380    Parameters
1381    ----------
1382    euler_pole
1383        NumPy Array containing the longitude [rad], latitude [rad], and rotation
1384        rate [rad/time] of the Euler pole.
1385    euler_pole_covariance
1386        If ``rotation_covariance`` was given, the propagated uncertainty for the Euler
1387        Pole for all three components.
1388
1389    Returns
1390    -------
1391    rotation_vector
1392        Rotation vector [rad/time] containing the diagonals of the :math:`3 \times 3`
1393        rotation matrix specifying the Euler pole in cartesian, ECEF coordinates.
1394    rotation_covariance
1395        If ``euler_pole_covariance`` was given, formal :math:`3 \times 3` covariance
1396        matrix [rad^2/time^2] of the rotation vector.
1397
1398    See Also
1399    --------
1400    rotvec2eulerpole : Inverse function
1401    """
1402    # readability
1403     = euler_pole[2]
1404    sinlat, coslat = np.sin(euler_pole[1]), np.cos(euler_pole[1])
1405    sinlon, coslon = np.sin(euler_pole[0]), np.cos(euler_pole[0])
1406    # rotation vector, eq. 5 (no scaling)
1407    _x =  * coslat * coslon
1408    _y =  * coslat * sinlon
1409    _z =  * sinlat
1410    rotation_vector = np.array([_x, _y, _z])
1411    # uncertainty, eq. 6 (no scaling)
1412    if euler_pole_covariance is not None:
1413        jac = np.array(
1414            [
1415                [- * coslat * sinlon, - * sinlat * coslon, coslat * coslon],
1416                [ * coslat * coslon, - * sinlat * sinlon, coslat * sinlon],
1417                [0,  * coslat, sinlat],
1418            ]
1419        )
1420        rotation_covariance = jac @ euler_pole_covariance @ jac.T
1421    # return
1422    if euler_pole_covariance is not None:
1423        return rotation_vector, rotation_covariance
1424    else:
1425        return rotation_vector
1426
1427
1428class Rheology(ABC):
1429    """
1430    Abstract base class for rheologies.
1431    """
1432
1433
1434class RateStateSteadyLogarithmic(Rheology):
1435    r"""
1436    Implement a steady-state rate-and-state rheology using the ageing law (effectively
1437    becoming a rate-dependent rheology) with velocity in logarithmic space defined by
1438
1439    :math:`f_{ss} = f_0 + (a - b) * \zeta = \tau / \sigma_E`
1440
1441    where :math:`f_{ss}` is the steady-state friction, :math:`f_0` is a reference
1442    friction, :math:`a` and :math:`b` are the rate-and-state frictional parameters,
1443    :math:`\zeta = \log (v / v_0)` is the logarithmic velocity, :math:`\tau` is the shear
1444    stress, and :math:`\sigma_E` is the effective fault normal stress.
1445    """
1446
1447    def __init__(
1448        self,
1449        v_0,
1450        alpha_h,
1451        alpha_h_mid=None,
1452        mid_transition=None,
1453        alpha_h_deep=None,
1454        deep_transition=None,
1455        boundary_width=None,
1456        alpha_h_boundary=None,
1457    ):
1458        r"""
1459        Setup the rheology parameters for a given fault.
1460
1461        Parameters
1462        ----------
1463        v_0 : float
1464            Reference velocity [m/s] used for the transformation into logarithmic space.
1465        alpha_h : float
1466            Rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E`,
1467            where :math:`a` and :math:`b` [-] are the rate-and-state frictional properties,
1468            and :math:`\sigma_E` [Pa] is effective fault normal stress.
1469        """
1470        self.alpha_h = float(alpha_h)
1471        r""" Rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa] """
1472        # input check
1473        assert not np.logical_xor(alpha_h_boundary is None, boundary_width is None)
1474        assert float(v_0) > 0, "RateStateSteadyLogarithmic needs to have positive v_0."
1475        # set number of variables
1476        self.n_vars = 2
1477        """ Number of variables to track by rheology [-] """
1478        # initialization
1479        self.v_0 = float(v_0)
1480        """ Reference velocity :math:`v_0` [m/s] """
1481        self.alpha_h = float(alpha_h)
1482        r""" Rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa] """
1483        self.alpha_h_mid = (
1484            float(alpha_h_mid) if alpha_h_mid is not None else self.alpha_h
1485        )
1486        r""" Middle rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa] """
1487        self.alpha_h_deep = (
1488            float(alpha_h_deep) if alpha_h_deep is not None else self.alpha_h_mid
1489        )
1490        r""" Deep rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa] """
1491        self.alpha_h_boundary = (
1492            float(alpha_h_boundary)
1493            if alpha_h_boundary is not None
1494            else self.alpha_h_deep
1495        )
1496        r""" Boundary-layer rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa] """
1497        self.mid_transition = None if mid_transition is None else float(mid_transition)
1498        """ Depth [m] for the middle transition point """
1499        self.deep_transition = (
1500            None if deep_transition is None else float(deep_transition)
1501        )
1502        """ (Upper) Depth [m] for the deep transition point """
1503        self.boundary_width = None if boundary_width is None else float(boundary_width)
1504        """ (Downdip) Width [m] of the deep transition point """
1505
1506    def get_param_vectors(self, patch_centroids, outer_vertices):
1507        r"""
1508        Calculate the depth-dependent array of :math:`\alpha_h`, assuming it
1509        varies log-linearly with depth.
1510        """
1511
1512        # input checks
1513        patch_depths = -patch_centroids[:, 2]
1514        assert np.all(patch_depths >= 0)
1515
1516        # first part: general depth-dependent alpha_h
1517        # start knots list
1518        knots = [np.min(patch_depths)]
1519        vals_alpha_h = [self.alpha_h]
1520        # add optional mid transition
1521        if self.mid_transition is not None:
1522            knots.append(self.mid_transition)
1523            vals_alpha_h.append(self.alpha_h_mid)
1524        # add optional deep transition
1525        if self.deep_transition is not None:
1526            knots.append(self.deep_transition)
1527            vals_alpha_h.append(self.alpha_h_deep)
1528        # add final value if necessary for constant alpha_h
1529        if len(knots) == 1:
1530            knots.append(np.max(patch_depths))
1531            vals_alpha_h.append(self.alpha_h_deep)
1532        vals_alpha_h = np.array(vals_alpha_h)
1533        # interpolate alpha_n and alpha_eff
1534        alpha_h_vec = 10 ** interp1d(
1535            knots, np.log10(vals_alpha_h), fill_value="extrapolate"
1536        )(patch_depths)
1537
1538        # second part: make borders to non-simulated patches gradually stronger
1539        if self.alpha_h_boundary is not None:
1540            # distances from inner patch centroids to vertices
1541            dists = cdist(patch_centroids, outer_vertices)
1542            # minimum distances
1543            min_dists = np.min(dists, axis=1)
1544            # alpha_h_vec if this distance was the only metric
1545            boundary_vec = (
1546                (self.boundary_width - min_dists)
1547                / self.boundary_width
1548                * np.log10(self.alpha_h_boundary)
1549            )
1550            # final alpha_h_vec is the element-wise maximum of the two
1551            alpha_h_vec = np.fmax(10**boundary_vec, alpha_h_vec)
1552
1553        # done
1554        return alpha_h_vec
1555
1556
1557class RateStateSteadyLogarithmic2D(Rheology):
1558    r"""
1559    Implement a 2D steady-state rate-and-state rheology using the aging law (effectively
1560    becoming a rate-dependent rheology) with velocity in logarithmic space defined by
1561
1562    :math:`f_{ss} = f_0 + (a - b) * \zeta = \tau / \sigma_E`
1563
1564    where :math:`f_{ss}` is the steady-state friction, :math:`f_0` is a reference
1565    friction, :math:`a` and :math:`b` are the rate-and-state frictional parameters,
1566    :math:`\zeta = \log (v / v_0)` is the logarithmic velocity, :math:`\tau` is the shear
1567    stress, and :math:`\sigma_E` is the effective fault normal stress.
1568
1569    The 2D spatial variation is implemented with B-Splines. Towards the boundaries
1570    of the simulated regions, the rheological strength is forced to a certain value
1571    regardless of the 2D spline-based variability.
1572    """
1573
1574    # helper class
1575    class CustomBasisFunction:
1576        def __init__(self, full_knots_depth, full_knots_horiz, degree, ix_d, ix_h):
1577            self.bd = BSpline.basis_element(
1578                full_knots_depth[ix_d : ix_d + degree + 2], extrapolate=False
1579            )
1580            self.bh = BSpline.basis_element(
1581                full_knots_horiz[ix_h : ix_h + degree + 2], extrapolate=False
1582            )
1583
1584        def __call__(self, d, h):
1585            return np.nan_to_num(self.bd(d)) * np.nan_to_num(self.bh(h))
1586
1587    def __init__(
1588        self,
1589        v_0,
1590        alpha_h_mat,
1591        degree=1,  # knots_depth=None, knots_horiz=None,
1592        boundary_width=None,
1593        alpha_h_boundary=None,
1594    ):
1595        r"""
1596        Setup the rheology parameters for a given fault.
1597
1598        Parameters
1599        ----------
1600        v_0 : float
1601            Reference velocity [m/s] used for the transformation into logarithmic space.
1602        alpha_h_mat : numpy.ndarray
1603            2D rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa],
1604            where :math:`a` and :math:`b` [-] are the rate-and-state frictional properties,
1605            and :math:`\sigma_E` [Pa] is effective fault normal stress.
1606            The first dimension corresponds to depth, the second to horizontal distance.
1607        degree : int
1608            Degree [-] of the B-Splines used to represent the 2D variability of `alpha_h_mat`.
1609        # knots_depth : list, optional
1610        #     If not `None`, a sorted list of knot values between 0 and 1 of fractional depths
1611        #     where the knots for the spline interpolation for `alpha_h_mat` are located.
1612        #     Defaults to uniform knot spacing.
1613        # knots_horiz : list, optional
1614        #     Same as `knots_depth` for for the horizontal direction.
1615        boundary_width : float
1616            The width of the transition zone [m] to the boundary `alpha_h` value.
1617        alpha_h_boundary : float
1618            The value of `alpha_h` [Pa] at the boundaries of the simulation.
1619        """
1620
1621        # input check
1622        assert not np.logical_xor(alpha_h_boundary is None, boundary_width is None)
1623        assert float(v_0) > 0, "RateStateSteadyLogarithmic needs to have positive v_0."
1624        assert (
1625            isinstance(alpha_h_mat, np.ndarray) and alpha_h_mat.ndim == 2
1626        ), "'alpha_h_mat' needs to be a 2D NumPy array."
1627
1628        # initialization
1629        self.n_vars = 2
1630        """ Number of variables to track by rheology [-] """
1631        self.v_0 = float(v_0)
1632        """ Reference velocity :math:`v_0` [m/s] """
1633        self.alpha_h_mat = alpha_h_mat.astype(float)
1634        r""" Rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa] """
1635        self.degree = int(degree)
1636        """ Degree of the B-Splines [-] """
1637        self.boundary_width = None if boundary_width is None else float(boundary_width)
1638        """ Width [m] of the boundary zone """
1639        self.alpha_h_boundary = (
1640            None if alpha_h_boundary is None else float(alpha_h_boundary)
1641        )
1642        r""" Boundary rate-and-state parameter :math:`(a - b) * \sigma_E` [Pa] """
1643
1644        # prepare 2d spline creation
1645        self.num_bases_depth = self.alpha_h_mat.shape[0]
1646        """ Number of bases [-] in the depth direction """
1647        self.num_bases_horiz = self.alpha_h_mat.shape[1]
1648        """ Number of bases [-] in the horizontal direction """
1649        num_knots_depth = self.num_bases_depth - self.degree + 1
1650        num_knots_horiz = self.num_bases_horiz - self.degree + 1
1651        inner_knots_depth = (
1652            np.linspace(0, 1, num=num_knots_depth)
1653            if num_knots_depth > 1
1654            else np.array([])
1655        )
1656        inner_knots_horiz = (
1657            np.linspace(0, 1, num=num_knots_horiz)
1658            if num_knots_horiz > 1
1659            else np.array([])
1660        )
1661        full_knots_depth = np.concatenate(
1662            [[0] * self.degree, inner_knots_depth, [1] * self.degree]
1663        )
1664        full_knots_horiz = np.concatenate(
1665            [[0] * self.degree, inner_knots_horiz, [1] * self.degree]
1666        )
1667
1668        # create 2D basis functions
1669        self.bases = np.array(
1670            [
1671                [
1672                    RateStateSteadyLogarithmic2D.CustomBasisFunction(
1673                        full_knots_depth, full_knots_horiz, self.degree, ix_d, ix_h
1674                    )
1675                    for ix_h in range(self.num_bases_horiz)
1676                ]
1677                for ix_d in range(self.num_bases_depth)
1678            ]
1679        )
1680        """ Matrix of 2D spline basis functions """
1681
1682    def get_param_vectors(
1683        self, patch_depths, patch_horiz, patch_centroids, outer_vertices
1684    ):
1685        r"""
1686        Calculate the 2D-varying array of :math:`\alpha_h` and how it is made.
1687        """
1688        # first part: general 2d-varying alpha_h
1689        bases_eval = np.stack(
1690            [b(patch_depths, patch_horiz) for b in self.bases.ravel()], axis=-1
1691        ).reshape(patch_depths.size, self.num_bases_depth, self.num_bases_horiz)
1692        alpha_h_vec_raw = 10 ** np.sum(
1693            bases_eval * np.log10(self.alpha_h_mat[None, :, :]), axis=(1, 2)
1694        )
1695        # get flattened indices of dominant bases
1696        dominant_bases = np.argmax(bases_eval.reshape(alpha_h_vec_raw.size, -1), axis=1)
1697
1698        # second part: make borders to non-simulated patches gradually stronger
1699        if self.alpha_h_boundary is None:
1700            alpha_h_vec = alpha_h_vec_raw
1701        else:
1702            # distances from inner patch centroids to vertices
1703            dists = cdist(patch_centroids, outer_vertices)
1704            # minimum distances
1705            min_dists = np.min(dists, axis=1)
1706            # alpha_h_vec if this distance was the only metric
1707            boundary_vec = 10 ** (
1708                (self.boundary_width - min_dists)
1709                / self.boundary_width
1710                * np.log10(self.alpha_h_boundary)
1711            )
1712            # final alpha_h_vec is the element-wise maximum of the two
1713            alpha_h_vec = np.fmax(boundary_vec, alpha_h_vec_raw)
1714            # set to NaN where the boundary condition took over
1715            bc_strongest = np.argmax(
1716                np.vstack([alpha_h_vec_raw, boundary_vec]), axis=0
1717            ).astype(bool)
1718            dominant_bases[bc_strongest] = -1
1719
1720        # done
1721        return alpha_h_vec, dominant_bases
1722
1723    def get_valid_domain(self, patch_depths, patch_horiz, ix_estim_rows, ix_estim_cols):
1724        """
1725        Calculate the domain where the given row and column indices are unaffected
1726        by the other indices.
1727        """
1728        # start again with bases evaluation
1729        bases_eval = np.stack(
1730            [b(patch_depths, patch_horiz) for b in self.bases.ravel()], axis=-1
1731        ).reshape(patch_depths.size, self.num_bases_depth, self.num_bases_horiz)
1732        # find all non-estimated rows and columns
1733        ix_const_rows = [
1734            i for i in range(self.num_bases_depth) if i not in ix_estim_rows
1735        ]
1736        ix_const_cols = [
1737            i for i in range(self.num_bases_horiz) if i not in ix_estim_cols
1738        ]
1739        # find all evaluation indices that have non-zero effects from ix_const_*
1740        ix_const_mat = ~np.logical_or(
1741            np.any(
1742                bases_eval[
1743                    np.ix_(
1744                        list(range(patch_depths.size)),
1745                        ix_const_rows,
1746                        list(range(self.num_bases_horiz)),
1747                    )
1748                ]
1749                != 0,
1750                axis=(1, 2),
1751            ),
1752            np.any(
1753                bases_eval[
1754                    np.ix_(
1755                        list(range(patch_depths.size)),
1756                        list(range(self.num_bases_depth)),
1757                        ix_const_cols,
1758                    )
1759                ]
1760                != 0,
1761                axis=(1, 2),
1762            ),
1763        )
1764        # done
1765        return ix_const_mat
1766
1767
1768class Fault3D:
1769    """
1770    Base class for the subduction fault mesh.
1771    """
1772
1773    # shorthands for specifying farfield motion type
1774    FARFIELD_MOTION_UNIFORM = 1
1775    FARFIELD_MOTION_ROTATION = 2
1776    FARFIELD_MOTION_EULER = 3
1777    FARFIELD_MOTION_PROVIDED = 4
1778
1779    def __init__(
1780        self,
1781        inner_mesh_files,
1782        asperity_mesh_files,
1783        lower_mesh_files,
1784        downdip_direction,
1785        mu,
1786        nu,
1787        v_s,
1788        farfield_motion,
1789        farfield_motion_type,
1790        max_simulated_distance,
1791        max_simulated_depth,
1792        orient_along=0,
1793        offset_lower=0,
1794        utmzone=None,
1795        lon0=None,
1796        lat0=None,
1797        K_inner_asperities=None,
1798        K_inner_inner=None,
1799        cross_sections=None,
1800    ):
1801        """
1802        Define the fault mesh of the subduction zone fault system, based on the
1803        Elastic Subducting Plate Model (ESPM) of [kanda2010]_.
1804
1805        The inner mesh consists of the asperities as well as the surrounding
1806        creeping patches, formulated as triangular dislocation elements.
1807
1808        The outer mesh consists of the boundary patches that are necessary
1809        to recover longterm surface displacement due to continuous fault slip.
1810
1811        Parameters
1812        ----------
1813        inner_mesh_files : list
1814            Path to `.tet` mesh file defining the inner mesh on the upper plate
1815            interface.
1816        asperity_mesh_files : list
1817            List of paths to `.tet` mesh files defining the upper plate interface's
1818            asperities, assumed to be within the inner mesh.
1819        lower_mesh_files : list
1820            List of paths to `.tet` mesh files defining the lower plate interface.
1821        downdip_direction : str
1822            Direction into which the inner mesh should be extended using the
1823            normal vectors. All other directions will be extended on constant
1824            boundary depth. Two-character code of sign `+-` and axes `xy`.
1825        mu : float
1826            Shear modulus [Pa]
1827        nu : float
1828            Poisson's ratio [-]
1829        v_s : float
1830            Shear wave velocity [m/s] in the fault zone.
1831        farfield_motion : numpy.ndarray
1832            Either a 1D array containing the uniform plate motion [m/s] in ENU for all patches,
1833            or an ECEF rotation vector [/Ma], a Longitude/Latitude/Rate Euler Pole [],
1834            or a 2D array containing the precomputed ENU plate velocity [m/s] at each patch.
1835        farfield_motion_type : int
1836            Describes the type of `farfield_motion` between `1` (uniform), `2`
1837            (ECEF rotation), `3` (Euler Pole), or `4` (precomputed).
1838        max_simulated_distance : float
1839            Maximum horizontal distance [m] from asperities until which to simulate patches
1840        max_simulated_depth : float
1841            Maximum depth [m] (positive) until which to simulate patches
1842        orient_along : float
1843            Angle [ counter-clockwise from east] of the subduction fault strike.
1844        offset_lower : float
1845            Additional offset the lower part of the mesh [m] (positive means upwards shift)
1846        utmzone : int, optional
1847            If `farfield_motion_type` is an ECEF rotation or Euler Pole, it is necessary to
1848            know in which coordinate system the mesh files are.
1849        lon0 : float, optional
1850            If there is a custom longitude offset [] used in calculating the mesh file
1851            UTM coordinates, provide it here.
1852        lat0 : float, optional
1853            If there is a custom latitude offset [] used in calculating the mesh file
1854            UTM coordinates, provide it here.
1855        K_inner_asperities : numpy.ndarray, optional
1856            Precomputed stress kernel from the asperities to the inner mesh [Pa/m]
1857        K_inner_inner : numpy.ndarray, optional
1858            Precomputed stress kernel within the inner mesh [Pa/m]
1859        cross_sections : list, optional
1860            Precomputed valid cross sections
1861        """
1862
1863        # input check
1864        assert isinstance(inner_mesh_files, list)
1865        assert isinstance(asperity_mesh_files, list)
1866        assert isinstance(lower_mesh_files, list)
1867        assert isinstance(downdip_direction, str)
1868        assert 1 <= farfield_motion_type <= 4
1869        assert isinstance(farfield_motion_type, int)
1870        if farfield_motion_type == 4:
1871            assert (
1872                isinstance(farfield_motion, np.ndarray)
1873                and (farfield_motion.ndim == 2)
1874                and (farfield_motion.shape[1] == 3)
1875            )
1876        else:
1877            assert (
1878                isinstance(farfield_motion, np.ndarray)
1879                and (farfield_motion.ndim == 1)
1880                and (farfield_motion.size == 3)
1881            )
1882        if farfield_motion_type in (2, 3):
1883            assert isinstance(utmzone, int), (
1884                f"For 'farfield_motion_type={farfield_motion_type}', "
1885                "an integer 'utmzone' needs to be provided."
1886            )
1887        use_normals = [False, False, False, False]
1888        if downdip_direction[0] == "+":
1889            if downdip_direction[1] == "x":
1890                use_normals[0] = True
1891            elif downdip_direction[1] == "y":
1892                use_normals[1] = True
1893        elif downdip_direction[0] == "-":
1894            if downdip_direction[1] == "x":
1895                use_normals[2] = True
1896            elif downdip_direction[1] == "y":
1897                use_normals[3] = True
1898        if not any(use_normals):
1899            raise ValueError(f"Can't parse 'use_normals' from {downdip_direction}.")
1900
1901        # material properties
1902        self.mu = float(mu)
1903        """ Shear modulus [Pa] """
1904        self.nu = float(nu)
1905        """ Poisson's ratio [-] """
1906        self.v_s = float(v_s)
1907        """ Shear wave velocity [m/s] in the fault zone """
1908        self.E = 2 * self.mu * (1 + self.nu)
1909        """ Young's modulus [Pa] of the fault zone """
1910        self.mu_over_2vs = self.E / (2 * (1 + self.nu) * 2 * self.v_s)
1911        """ Radiation damping term [Pa * s/m] """
1912        self.farfield_motion_type = farfield_motion_type
1913        """ Type of farfield motion used to calculate plate velocity """
1914        self.utmzone = int(utmzone) if utmzone is not None else None
1915        """ UTM zone number of fault coordinates """
1916
1917        # simulation boundaries
1918        assert max_simulated_distance > 0
1919        self.max_simulated_distance = float(max_simulated_distance)
1920        """ Maximum horizontal distance [m] from asperities until which to simulate patches """
1921        assert max_simulated_depth > 0
1922        self.max_simulated_depth = float(max_simulated_depth)
1923        """ Maximum depth [m] (positive) until which to simulate patches """
1924        self.orient_along = float(orient_along)
1925        """ Main orientation of the subduction zone [] """
1926        self.offset_lower = float(offset_lower)
1927        """ Offset applied to the lower mesh files [m] """
1928
1929        # create asperities mesh
1930        vertices_asperities, triangles_asperities, match_sources = combine_tet(
1931            *asperity_mesh_files, return_sources=True
1932        )
1933        # correct custom UTM by applying average shift
1934        if (self.utmzone is not None) and ((lon0 is not None) or (lat0 is not None)):
1935            offset_en = (
1936                correct_custom_utm(vertices_asperities[:, :2], self.utmzone, lon0, lat0)
1937                - vertices_asperities[:, :2]
1938            ).mean(axis=0)
1939            vertices_asperities[:, :2] += offset_en
1940        assert (
1941            vertices_asperities[:, 2].max() <= 0
1942        ), "Found up-coordinates larger than 0 in the asperities mesh."
1943        vertices_asperities, triangles_asperities = force_normals(
1944            vertices_asperities, triangles_asperities, normals_up=False
1945        )
1946        self.asperities_vertices = vertices_asperities
1947        """ Vertex coordinates for the asperities mesh [m] """
1948        self.asperities_triangles = triangles_asperities
1949        """ Triangle definitions for the asperities mesh [-] """
1950        self.asperities_patches = self.asperities_vertices[self.asperities_triangles]
1951        """ Asperities patches """
1952        self.asperities_polygons = [
1953            shapely.Polygon(arr) for arr in self.asperities_patches
1954        ]
1955        """ List of all asperity triangles as Shapely Polygons """
1956        self.asperities_centroids = np.mean(self.asperities_patches, axis=1)
1957        """ Centroids of asperities patches [m] """
